text.tspan: After Mika gets the kids off to school, she runs errands and then
goes to work, frequently skipping lunch. She can’t bring along an
energy bar to snack on at work because her school is a nut-free
zone. She also tries to eat a gluten-free diet, so she rules out energy
bars because she doesn’t think there are any options.
• Being able to bring outside food to her job
• Not enough time to eat lunch
• No easy snack options to bring to work
Mika, a married mother of two,
elementary school. She and her husband renovated a vintage
camper which they use to escape into the mountains on summer
Allison often works long hours on tight deadlines and doesn’t have
time to stop and cook a meal. This is especially true around lunch
time, when she frequently goes without. She has purchased energy
bars in the past, but she is vegan and the few options that she has
found are too sweet and give her the feeling that she has just eaten
dessert rather than consumed a meal.
• Not enough time to eat lunch
business. On her rare days off
she rides her bike along the lake shore or goes paddle-boarding in a
nearby state park. She spends every other Sunday with a ten-year-
old that she mentors through Big Brothers/Big Sisters.
Julian works long hours and frequently skips lunch and sometimes
dinner when he works late. His office supplies the break room with
energy and fitness bars, but Julian doesn’t eat them because he
thinks they all taste like protein powder. He would be more inclined
to try an energy bar if it promised good flavor and sustenance.
• A meal he can easily eat as his desk
• An energy bar that makes him feel full
• Not enough time to eat lunch/dinner
• Energy bars that taste powdery and bad
• Energy bars that only target athletic types
Julian moved from the Midwest to the Research Triangle last year
. He loves exploring his new city and
sampling southern cooking. On weekends he tries to get out and
hike parts of the Appalachian Trail.
